body.p: Another deal with three potential strains. Game can be made in notrump, hearts, or clubs from one side or the other.
If North is declarer in , East can set it with a spade lead.
Declarer cannot play the , because he will eventually have to take the club finesses, and will then lose four spades and a club. So declarer must duck, West winning the .
Having grabbed a spade trick, West can shift to a diamond, and East/West eventually get two spades, two diamonds, and a club.
Declared by South, though, makes. There is no way to put West in to lead diamonds.

If South declares , he will have trouble after a diamond lead. We know, for instance, that if South draws trumps, he can come up with at most nine tricks, since it reverts to the notrump situation discussed above - East gets two diamonds, a spade, and a club.

So South has to score an extra trump trick. Ruffing clubs in hand is fruitless - he would be ruffing winners. So South wins the first diamond, leads a heart to the ten and leads a spade. East flies the ace and continues with two diamonds, forcing the ruff to occur in the diamond suit. The situation is:
Stuck in dummy, South cannot get back to his hand to finish off the trumps.
The diamond lead kills the entry to the South hand.

If North is declaring , however, East cannot take more than three tricks. If he leads the diamond king to kill the entry to trumps, he has just given up a trick, and declarer can simply allow West to win a trump. All other leads sacrifice either tricks or tempo.
The contracts are the easiest to follow.
With West on lead against a club game, a diamond lead immediately sets up a third defensive trick.
Any lead from East gives North time to set up a spade to pitch his diamond loser.
